If they came from a human then give them the rights you would give a human, if they came from a pig then you should not have any difficulty with that thing, if it came from a frog then the animal rights that apply to a frog should apply to this robot. But because the way that these cells are combined with other cells is the only thing that humans actually partook in, then something tells me that this would be akin to surgery. In surgery a doctor that has never done anything that directly or indirectly affected the life of the patient, if they do open heart surgery they are changing the position of the heart cells, then the cells will fuse together. Like the cells of the frogs being removed from their initial position and then fusing together because of human intervention, the researchers took them from pre-existing frogs, if they were the ones to bread these frogs from two other frogs and on top of this oh, the only things that went into their bodies were things that were pre-approved by the researchers. Then this in my opinion would be a true living robot, besides taking every single protein and painstakingly applying them together, or genetically Engineering in organism using crisper. But the point remains that the only things going into that thing would have to come from the researchers. That is what I would consider to truly be something that was made by man, not something that man had changed. In this case they would not have taken some cells from a frog they found in the wild, remove them from the initial position in the Frog, and then reposition then in a manner that caused them to fuse. No, this scenario means that they put into the frogs what the frogs are made out of, they are are the people who allowed those frogs to be born, and all the things that they put into them would then be what form the Frog. This would mean that that the frog is entirely made out of what the researchers had approved, this means that they truly made it, then when they take these cells and do to them what day did to the real frog cells. This would be something that would be truly man-made, and it's organic, this would be alive, this is a true living room, if you're going to call this thing that they did in real life a living robot, then open heart surgery that has been completely successful would be a robot, even if a whole calendar year past. But this, this is like surgery, they did surgery to the frogs that were not consenting and had no health issues, but let's ignore that, they did surgery to the frogs, the surgery caused pieces of living tissue to come off a lot of the cells removed in surgery may indeed be living individual cells. And there is a literal surgery where living cells, which would then be classified as tissue would be moved from one point of the body to another. This is like what's going on here, it's still part of the body because it's a different grouping of cells from the Frog, and it's being removed like a skin graft, this is a skin graft with included muscle, and the thing about rights, personally I think it would make sense not that it is necessarily the right way to go about it, but it would make sense to you give the uses xenobots the rights that would go to whatever organism their cells are harvested from. Consciousness is not emergent. That is a topic secular science will never be able to understand because they begin with a presumption that certain circumstances do not exist. They cant find the answer because they have already rejected it.

In reality, consciousness can not emerge from the physical world. Consciousness is none physical. Yes it requires hardware to function through, an interface of sorts, which without, consciousness does not operate.

None physical does not arrive from physical. Science actually denies the existence of consciousness. And yet no scientist does. They just cherry pick what suits them then.

One might say, well ha, doesnt the fact that a damaged brain impairs consciousness prove that consciousness comes from the brain? Well no. That doesn't answer the question of origin at all.

Just like how a malfunctioning computer program caused by a malfunctioning hard drive, doesnt prove that the program emerged from a hard drive. In fact, the programme is again a none physical entity. It is only brought to life through a physical entity. You could have a programme with its very code in your mind, write it on paper even, though that's physical, and by this, it exists, but it is not yet brought into operation, it needs the correct physical medium to operate.

In both cases, the programme and the consciousness, they are created outside of the machine that runs them. It doesn't matter if you use the computer itself to write the code, a code can be written on anything, the computer is simply the machine that is designed an created to run that programme.

Our designer and creator is fortunately far above and beyond us, he is able to create minds that's can learn and adapt individually. His programmes, once plugged in, are self aware. A dream that science will never be able to achieve with AI or these biological bots. We dont have the capability of creating life, though they keep on trying. Very interesting and exciting, but the implications are significant. I like the idea of potentially breaking down plastics in particular. However this, along with its applications in medicine and pretty much every else has to be weighed very heavily.

Since they will be asked to coexist within the context of an already existing ecosystem, they undoubtedly will interact in the food chain. Competing for resources, they will likely modulate the populations of competing organisms.

Your body is a much smaller scale example, and it frees us from the necessity of engineering in survival mechanisms. This is because a human is a small enough environment that regular booster shots of some treatment regimen are feasible as opposed to the sheer volume of the ocean necessitating the xenobot's ability to self sustain its population.

Similar to applications of AI, we need to consider safety of implementation very seriously, and be guarded against recklessness and exploitation.

Did a little google search for enzymes and polyethelene (HDPE=milk jug LDPE=plastic bag), and found this article about two strains of Penicillium (fungus) that have "plastic degrading abilities." It certainly would be an interesting challenge to assemble xenobots to digest plastics that these fungi can, but there are a lot of hurdles I can think of off the bat.
The challenges a xenobot would have to face are myriad. A few I can think of right now:
-Surviving the high sodium environment of the ocean
-Surviving the microorganisms that would make a snack of the bot
-Encountering the plastic particles, either deliberitely or bumping into them
-Adhering to or absorbing the particles (adherence being able to tackle larger pieces)
-Digesting the plastic.
-Dealing with byproducts of digestion

Then something to consider beyond just designing the xenobot with these features is the balance between functioning long enough to eliminate plastic waste, but not so long they become their own kind of pollution.


With all these things to consider, it might be easier to take an existing organism and use recombinant DNA technology to place the enzyme gene into it. A phytoplankton that normally hangs out near the surface for sunlight might be successful enough as a species to also bump into the plastic that's floating at the surface.

I was thinking, as biotech is a thing. For example, mechanical limbs, they could create a mechanical skeleton, which would connect directly with a biological brain, if they can create such a thing.
Because that way it is technically alive, as it uses the brain to make its own decisions, but uses the skeleton like a human would use a mechanical limb. Which is different to a robot, with a metal, programmed “brain”. It might be able to make its own decisions, but it’s still programmed in the end. So that wouldn’t be classed as living? But if the main part of the decision making “part” (like a brain), was biological, then to me, that’s technically alive. They could also fit these new “human robots” with brain chips, to help them connect to devices, but with also human like thinking, however, with this comes issues, as humans have issues as it is. But a “robot” is programmed, and only made to do what it has been programmed to do, however, this can be altered, or even the robot itself could justify something that we would find, not acceptable. So for me, it’s just weighing the pros and cons, and whether they would give a “human robot” actual rights, as it would technically be alive, unlike a “robot”.

What I would like to envisage is how these organic robots would converge with non organic robots, how would that be possible? Would they be able to reproduce eventually somehow with non organic robots, or would they become distinct species and not be able to reproduce with them?

I think we have to redefine our societal prescribed notion of what constitutes a robot, to fully understand these, because they don't look like factory robots, robots in films or robots in real life like Asimo. And of course how these could progress, size, brain power, abilities, would they be like humans or different?

They had to use organic cellular material to make the robots, so they come from an animal background, hence the unpredictable element. They almost seem like a hybrid of robot behaviour with animal cell reproduction.

Um Actually this isn’t the first people have discussed this, nor are biocomputers anything new. Aside from existing in literature since who knows when, biocomputers have existed for decades, and genetic engineering (reprogramming of living organisms) has existed for centuries. They have many medical, culinary, et cetera applications which we reap the benefits of here in the USA (and so far as I know Europe, Australia, and other parts of the developed world too) in almost every aspect of our healthcare and genetically modified food.

The type you’re calling “living robots” are called Biomechanical Computers. The majority of the applications you’re referring to have been possible for years, only the use of programable human cells; AKA stem cells; and any form of genetic modification of animals; such as using stem cells to create more of the persons own cells that fight off cancer and disease; is illegal (last I checked). The official reason being some drivel about disrespecting God.

In the early 2000s the news stations all showed a montage of a veterans entire finger growing back over several treatments with stem cells before they were made illegal and the research censored. The discovery of how to create stem cells in a lab was exciting... until it was made illegal with basically no chance of that ever changing. I can’t believe you thought this was like some new discovery, next you’re going to tell me you’ve never heard of biohackers or cyborgs hahaha. Hell nowadays it might be cheaper for me to just genetically modify my own multicolored fluorescent bacteria than to buy decoration lights and pay the extra in the electricity bills. I could probably find biohackers with the stuff I need online, easily since biohacking (private genetic engineering) isn’t technically illegal (yet).

I think there are so many better chemotaxic ways to get these things to move and respond to their environments that giving them anything resembling a pain receptor would, in and of itself, but utterly unethical. As for emergent consciousness, I believe that consciousness emerges from sensory perception combined with the brain's ability to process the data received by those senses, and that there's a "critical mass" of sorts where a brain becomes self-aware and conscious in the way ours is. Unfortunately, we only have a single data point in regards to this to really experiment with, being that our human relatives have all gone extinct. Without yet knowing where that critical mass is, I think it would be ethically and morally responsible to experiment with these things at least up until the point that we suspect or know that they are emergently conscious. Then an entirely new frontier can be explored in giving them rights. Up until that point, however, they're biochemical tools that we should experiment with and exploit in any way we can.

I think this opens up the question: "Where is the proof for the sanity of the rights we attribute to humans?" And "what exactly are they..?" Is there even a global consensus? Shouldn't that be discussed, before we discuss if they should be attributed to willfully constructed things, that may or may not evolve into other things?
It might shed some light on these more basic questions, but at this stage, that is the only imaginable use of such questions of rights for something non-human. Any other form is not yet capable of speaking for themselves, so there is a lot of guesswork and interpretation involved.
For instance, what does "feeling pain" even mean, when we allow fishing on the basis that fish don't feel pain and humans report vastly different pain-thresholds and will in some experiments even choose to endure more discomfort in situations that defy logic..?

And is attributing a quite innocent-seeming "right" historically been any use to humans, if you cannot enforce it for everyone or chance the way people think?
Look at how the "right to pursue happiness" led to desctructive, uncontrolleable capitalism. It has even fed back into extremists beliefs. It arguably provided less inequality, but on a much more massive scale. It also led to a more entrenched belief in race, both it's existence and importance, then even in the time when slaves were exploited.

Also, what kept plaguing me during this video: Why the emphasis on the value of the individual, while this value varies famously in different cultures? Who is deemed "right" here and for what reason, that you can actually back up with some facts or statistics?
Ethics break down really fast whenever you have to consider the lesser of two evils.
And I'd argue that with human rights this is always the case at the moment. As we cannot even ensure all humans basic human rights, extending human rights to constructs seems like an overreaching discussion, that will very quickly descend into expressing non-factual sentiments and do nothing than reflect cultural biases about individuality and rights.
The more unenlightened responses may be interesting when studied statistically and with some detachment, but I see no scenario in which these questions will yield anything ground breaking or even mildly productive.

Me, a biologist: This is an interesting new technique, but let's not overstate what's actually being done here.  This is manually picking up ~1,000 unmodified cells and sticking them together in a slightly different blob.  An animal is trillions of cells. This isn't even close to a new living thing.  It's a mildly modified tissue type, the genius is still in nature itself. I can imagine useful applications for these slight tweaks of existing biology.

I'm not sure that predictability is a pertinent criterion to determine if something is a robot or a natural living being. I see why the guy chose to use it (we can consider that artificial objects are designed by humans, and therefore have a predetermined function, action or motion) but it is not very rigorous, in my opinion.

Some natural phenomena can be predictible while some artificial (human made) creations can be unpredictable. I imagine that those who build robots and AIs are studying the behaviours of their creations, and that it can surprise them (even though they are the inventors).

The motion of a simple pendulum is predictable but when you attach a simple pendulum to another one, the motion of the system (a double pendulum) is very sensitive to initial conditions and therefore almost impossible to predict.

I think that the old problem of the stability of the solar system is another example of a natural phenomenon which isn't that predictable (a two-body problem is not hard to solve but as soon as you add a third body, the prediction depends a lot on the initial conditions, and that is what is called chaos).

It's amazing how many new things are coming along. It was way back in 1970 that Alvin and Heidi Toffler wrote Future Shock, which described how the speed of our technological advancement was affecting us.

But it wasn't happening nearly as quickly back then as it is now.

This is a new one on me. Am I frightened? Nah. We are closer to uplifting cats or developing intelligent computer programs than we are of assembling cells into something that might have rights. And, when it really comes down to it, the questions will have been thoroughly discussed by the time we are able to put together anything sapient.

While the current batch are being made by technicians with tweezers, I expect that later generations will be made with 3D printers. We are already printing organs, so these bio bots are a logical use for the printers.

Since they are assembled with a machine from existing cells, the DNA doesn't code for the cells' configuration. That means that they will not be self-replicating. That is, unless we find a way to make them so. If we do, I hope we think really hard about it first, and carefully isolate the results.

I like the idea of using them for medical purposes. I can foresee a time when we will get an implant that monitors our bodies and prints out biobots as needed. I can also see a time when people will use them for cosmetic surgery and body modification. Wanna be a furry? Go for it! Love basketball or football, but don't have the body for it? "Living robot" is a pretty misleading statement. It's made out of animal cells, sure, but the structure overall misses several of the core characteristics of life. (reproduction, passing on of traits, homeostasis)
It's not really any more of a 'living robot' than a protein is (or, going in the opposite direction, a group of people tied together at the ankles following instructions)

Also, while this is more of a personal opinion, I don't think the ethical question changes any just because we're suddenly using animal cells. Intelligence, suffering, etc are pretty subjective. Any machine that can observe a situation and make an assessment could be said to be intelligent, and if that machine is designed to avoid a certain stimulus, that stimulus could be consider 'pain' or 'discomfort.' Whether it's made of silicon or frog muscles doesn't change that.

You know, with as far as science and our understanding of how the world works has advanced at this point, we have the potential to do damn near just about anything if we try hard enough it seems like. The possibilities just seem endless to me. We can literally create new life from life, we can clone life, we can genetically modify life to make it be almost whatever we want it to be, yet of course, humans being humans, we will and probably have already found a shit ton of ways to abuse this power. To do bad things with it... I mean the moral weight of it all is one thing, even if you do remove all the religious and personal beliefs and just look at it from a purely logical standpoint: if we can create living beings or organisms PERIOD, then they are really no different from all other forms of life. They can probably think, feel, and act just like all other advanced life on earth. Yet with each negative there are also positives. Perhaps we could clone animals in massive quantities to slaughter them (humanly or non humanly) for their resources and food, this could benifit mankind as a whole, solve world hunger even. but then the "lesser" beings, the animals, COULD live a pretty awful life. I like to think of the clone issue as how it was shown in the Star Wars The Clone Wars television series, where clones who all were living, breathing, feeling human beings were born for one singular purpose: to fight and die for a war they didnt understand and had no choice in weather or not they could fight in it. Pretty harsh and bleak take on things but i also feel it is the best representation of what a real life scenario would be like. And why do i focus on clones here so much? Becuase they arent any different from a completely new life form being made by humans playing god. They, like clones, still think and feel.. They're still living... So i just hope humanity doesnt treat them like a tool. Like slaves to their cause. Becuase history tells plenty of how we've already done that before. It's nothing new. Slavery is something humanity has done since the ancient Egyptions and probably long before the Egyptions as well. Now, the choice is in the hands of the current generation of humans weather or not to continue this habit...

Here's the thing....

I've thought about it a lot, and at the bottom of our problems is that we are at the very beginning of getting out of the Dark Ages. What this boils down to is this: Energy.

Energy is able to make life AMAZING. Life LOVES energy and is an attempt to access as much of it as possible. Earthlings, who have (perhaps uniquely) evolved a transcendent consciousness, now have the ability to access millions of times more energy than biology alone was able to access. We also want more power, which is essentially the speed at which you can access energy to do work.

Unlimited energy and power essentially could make human life a Utopia. There are many problems we cannot solve currently because we are limited by this tiny trickle of energy and power we have, compared to the massive amounts we will have in the future. If you don't believe me, just look at how energy consumption has changed from 1920 to 2020! Electricity is still a VERY recent technology. Hell, we couldn't even support pocket phone computers, which we now all have, 20 years ago, because we didn't have good enough batteries back then. We really still don't have good batteries, yet, compared to what is coming. If the Green New Deal takes effect, our relationship to energy will accelerate a lot. We are going to get good at accessing energy and power and it can solve virtually all of problems, if we do it right, since we are also getting Quantum Computers and A.I. Essentially, once you have those working, you can just throw more energy at any problem and get more powerful answers, thus solving all your issues, if you do it right.


BUT, there is this unfortunate corollary: access to large amounts of energy and power also gives you the ability to do great damage physically. If you use this energy as a weapon, you end up becoming like the Empire in Star Wars: the Death Star is just a really concentrated source of energy and has the ability to generate large amounts of power. This allows it to destroy entire planets.

But more generally:


more power = more destructive weapons.


But we aren't going to live like cavepeople. We already worked hard to get to this place, and the price was already a potential nuclear holocaust that could literally destroy EVERY SINGLE HUMAN ON THE PLANET. We live DAILY with this reality right now, and that's why it's pretty scary when we elect a crazy man to be president.

But we aren't going to go back to being cavepeople. Sorry. It just isn't much fun to live like that.

So we MUST PASS AN INTERNATIONAL BAN ON WEAPONIZING ANY NEW TECHNOLOGY, period.

That means, we will still have guns and all the weapons we have developed so far. But new technology should be OUTRIGHT banned from weaponizing. The penalties should be stiff for this.

That one act would solve most of our troubles going forward, to the extent we integrate it into our culture, worldwide, as well. We have done similarly for chemical and biological weapons. Although terroristic groups still occasionally utilize them, as a planet, we are not particularly under threat of them as we once were.

Next will be nuclear weapons.

But we should STOP ALL NEW WEAPONIZATIONS OF TECHNOLOGY going forward. It's the only way to be sure.

Otherwise, this ability to destroy human life in a few seconds will only grow worse and worse and we'll have the ability to blow up planets or destroy all life on earth before we know it.

comment_text: This is equivocating the word "robot." Don't get me wrong this is an amazing achievement. However, this type of presentation misrepresents what is actually going on. In the original paper, the authors do NOT refer to the organism as a robot. They have manipulated the structures of living microorganisms to behave in a (somewhat) predictable way. That is a far cry from robotics which necessitates some level of a control system.

I don't really agree with the validity of the ethical implications of Xenobots.
I find that it is really easy for the public to jump straight to the "robot apocalypse" discussion due to pop culture, but it is important to note that these robots made of organic materials is just pretty much the same thing (at the core) as building a normal robot with metals and control systems with a larger exploration rate. It's just that they replaced the materials with preexisting/self-generating organic materials, which scientists were able to do for around a decade now with the IPS cells.
It is also important to note that these multi-cellular creatures do not possess the complex neural network function to produce something as complex as consciousness. We don't even know how consciousness emerged from random networks of neurons, and therefore it is pretty unlikely that researchers are able to even begin to successfully model consciousness, even in a computer simulation.

Does it eat? Does it reproduce? This robot is not in any way a living organism. It's just a few naturally pre-programmed cells doing their thing. I admit, there are great possibilites with this technology, but this is not life in the slightest. And as for the ethics of it, you can do whatever you want with it (for good, that is...). It has no more consciousness than a rock. I mean, it's made of only 2 types of cells, has no definite organs or tissues, and doesn't even have any sensory cells. Most plants are more complex and advanced than this thing, but who on earth would argue that plant are conscious? Besides, no one seems to mind ripping up weeds or tearing ears of corn off their stalks, so if there's no ethical issue there, why should there be an ethical issue with Xenobot? I agree that this is a fantastic step in science, but don't make a big thing out of nothing.

This all "robot apocalypse" might be the dumbest fear in the last couple of years.
A robot is not alive, it will never be alive, it doesn't have a consciousness and will never have one; a robot only does what is programmed to do.
If a robot picks a gun and kills you is because you gave it that "ability" and as such is not it's fault and you deserved it because of that.
Who in their right mind gives the ability to kill to a robot?!?

As for ethics, there are no ethics for things that are not alive, and to be alive you need a consciousness, a "soul".
If a robot "feels pain" is because you gave it that capacity and as such it mimics it.
There is no ethics for something you built as if it was a person because there is no point or logic in giving pain receptors (for example) to a machine.
I find hilarious when people speak about consciousness and AI, when we don't know what consciousness is in the first place.
Science has no understanding how thoughts exist and how we think, we all are equal in biology and as such we should all act and think alike, BUT WE DON'T, AND WE DON'T KNOW WHY....but we want to make robots have the ability to think and make decisions and have a "consciousness".

Scrabbling. Heeding the strategy of going for the shorter, more valuable
word over the longer cheaper word, our final play was “Bon,” which–as
luck would have it!–happens to be a Japanese Buddhist festival,
and not, as I had originally asserted while laying the tiles on the
board, one half of a chocolate-covered cherry treat. Anyway, the
strategy worked. My team only lost by 53 points instead of 58.


Just the day before, our host had written of the challenges
of writing short. In journalism–my friend’s chosen trade, and mostly my
own, too–Mark Twain’s observation undoubtedly applies: “I didn’t have
time to write a short letter, so I wrote a long one instead.” The
principle holds across genres, in letters, reporting, and other writing.
It’s harder to be concise than to blather. (Full disclosure, this blog
post will clock in at a blather-esque 803 words.) Good writing is boiled
down, not baked full of air like a souffl??. No matter how yummy
souffl??s may be. Which they are. Yummy like a Grisham novel.




Lately, I’ve been noticing how my sentences have a tendency to keep
going when I write them onscreen. This goes for concentrated writing as
well as correspondence. (Twain probably believed that correspondence, in
an ideal world, also demands concentration. But he never used email.)
Last week I caught myself packing four conjunctions into a three-line
sentence in an email. That’s inexcusable. Since then, I have tried to
eschew conjunctions whenever possible. Gone are the commas, the and’s,
but’s, and so’s; in are staccato declaratives. Better to read like bad
Hemingway than bad Faulkner.




Length–as we all know, and for lack of a more original or effective
way of saying it–matters. But (ahem), it’s also a matter of how you use
it. Style and length are technically two different things.




Try putting some prose onscreen, though, and they mix themselves up
pretty quickly. This has much to do with the time constraints we claim
to feel in the digital age. We don’t have time to compose letters and
post them anymore–much less pay postage, what with all the banks
kinda-sorta losing our money these days–so we blast a few emails. We
don’t have time to talk, so we text. We don’t have time to text to
specific people, so we update our Facebook status. We don’t have time to
write essays, so we blog.


I’m less interested by the superficial reduction of words–i.e. the
always charming imho or c u l8r–than the genres in which those
communications occur: blogs, texts, tweets, emails. All these
interstitial communiques, do they really re

Title click bait. It isn't living traditional "robot" because it is carbon based (natural/biological)... however, the quote that entirely new living organism/species is more apropos . They sound like a combination of cells that can be programmable. And okay, consciousness claimed as an emergent property is still a heavily philosophical debate buy both the ancients and modern philosophers. So, that was a huge assumption of what, how and where "consciousness" comes from. There are many more theories, an emergent property giving rise to human consciousness is one out of many theories. Is being able to do things actually consciousness? Or is it just like a brain stem where it's instinct no conscious control over it. Or is it just what is programmed to do? What level / line does this assumption of consciousness as an emergent property, then lead to ethical / moral questions? (we can't even agree for human on one universal ethical theory much less for these new living and programmable organisms. Don't even get me started about the brief sentence or mention about the ethics of all this. If that is thrown in an important video like this, you've got to make it longer or explain in multiple videos metaphysics first as a branch including ethics, then also the various theories about consciousness and why you picked 'consciousness is an emergent property' as your theory that is correct about consciousness. I think deeper research was needed or some more (broader) research into philosophy and organic chem etc. needed to be considered and explained.

I don’t think we should be calling them robots since they aren’t technically robots. I think the name just leaves too much room for misinterpretation. It’s pretty cool and exciting that science can do this kind of stuff now and if it could help save lives and save our planet it would be incredible. Imagine donating cells like how people donate blood and then those cells are used to clean out oceans. Or cells leftover as waste products from an operation being used later in life to cure yourself of cancer. There’s just so much potential here. In regards to ethics I think it would almost be harder to create lifeforms in a way that would warrant them rights equivalent to animals or humans. Like that it would take a conscious and persistent effort to do so. I don’t think we would do it by accident. However, as the organisms become more complex and develop more emergent behavior this isn’t to say that they wouldn’t (in a sense) evolve on their own. But evolution also takes time. It’s hard to make predictions on something we’ve had no past experience with. As long as we remain adaptable and curious (which shouldn’t be a problem) I think almost anything is possible. If we’re as careful as we are bold we should be able to safely and ethically change the world.

Man, I really want the implications to be positive, but my mind goes to things like extremist groups using xenobots for nefarious purposes. Here’s my take on this topic from what I can tell from this video (the first I’ve heard of xenobots): first, I like their name— foreign workers. Accurate, from what I can tell. Also, I think the ethics of this aren’t as nuanced as you’re thinking. (No offense.) If part of the xenobots’ job is to feel pain and respond to it, then we shouldn’t feel guilty about the fact that we are inflicting pain on them, since it’s in the job description. Like, I don’t know, firefighters. Their job is to put out fires, or in a more general sense, respond to emergencies. If we think of the xenobots the same way, then we can draw parallels: it’s important for them to be kept safe, but their job is dangerous, and we (and they, if sentience is achieved) know that it comes with the territory. Yes, it’s regrettable if they are lost, but the risks were known.

Does that make any sense, or do I sound coldhearted?

This is definitely a groundbreaking proof-of-concept in showing the potential for advancement in microbiology and medicine at the very least. If we are able to further our understanding and better manipulate the behavior of those cell-stacks, then we may be able to do some of the things mentioned in the video, such as use them to clear blocked arteries or assist in removing damaged tissue ie cancer tumors, etc.

What I don't agree with is the overdramatizing terminology of calling them robots. It's said that scientists made use of heart and skin cells from frogs. If so, then those cells are alive in the first place, and putting 2 different types of cells doesn't suddenly make a robot. It's literally how tissues are made, by combining multiple cells in a way that individually, they each serve their own purpose, and collectively they are able to perform a greater function by their collective efforts. In this case, the skin cells may provide mass and weight as a sort of center of gravity while the heart cells contract and propel the cell mass.

With regards to the matter of debating ethics, and whether the newly formed cell masses have rights, I'm going with a definite "no". Those cell masses have no consciousness whatsoever, which is the main point and end goal of the experiment, if I'm not mistaken. The scientists are trying to create something that can be made to behave exactly like is desired, and this behavior is ultimately intended to be replicable. I can imagine it like this: we humans can "will" our fingers to flex. We can flex and relax our limbs and fingers as much as we want, and by doing so in a certain manner, we can accomplish tasks like holding a cup, or opening a door by turning the door knob. One of the goals is to replicate this act of exercising control over the behavior of the "xenobot", which has no consciousness of their own, much like our muscle fibers in our arms have no mind, but react to our will via the transmitted signals in our nervous systems as cues or triggers to activate. So, "no" I don't believe they ought to have rights and it is not unethical to pursue this field.
